dishes.brief: Mixed rice with vegetables and egg

dishes.description: Korea's iconic mixed rice bowl — sautéed spinach, bean sprouts, carrots, zucchini, and mushrooms arranged over steamed rice with a fried egg and fiery gochujang. You mix everything together before eating. Think of it as Korea's answer to a thali: many distinct flavors combined into one balanced meal, similar to how you'd mix dal, sabzi, and rice together on your plate.

ingredients.name: Gochujang
ingredients.explanation: Fermented red chili paste — sweet, spicy, and savory. Korea's equivalent of a versatile chutney, used in almost every meal.

dishes.explanation: A balanced, colorful bowl that's one of Korea's most iconic dishes. The mix-it-yourself format means you control the ratio of rice to toppings. Vegetarian versions without meat are widely available.

culturalTerms.explanation: Means 'mixed' — you stir everything together before eating
Means 'rice' — the foundation of the dish
Hot stone bowl — creates a crispy rice crust at the bottom, similar to tahdig

dishes.description: Bouncy sweet potato glass noodles stir-fried with colorful julienned vegetables, beef strips, and a glossy soy-sesame sauce. The noodles are translucent and chewy — nothing like wheat noodles. If you enjoy the texture of falooda noodles or sevai, you'll love these. A festive dish served at Korean celebrations, much like how pulao appears at Indian gatherings.

ingredients.name: Sweet potato noodles
ingredients.explanation: Dangmyeon — chewy, translucent noodles made from sweet potato starch. Glassy and springy, unlike any wheat pasta.

dishes.explanation: A festive dish traditionally served at Korean celebrations and holidays. Mild and sweet rather than spicy — one of the safest bets if you're cautious about heat.

culturalTerms.explanation: Sweet potato starch noodles — the translucent, bouncy noodles that define japchae

dishes.description: A fiery, deeply savory stew built on aged fermented kimchi, simmered with pork belly, soft tofu, and green onions. Served bubbling in a stone pot with steamed rice on the side. The tangy fermented funk of aged kimchi is somewhat like achaar meets a spicy rasam — sour, hot, and deeply comforting. Every Korean household has their own recipe.

ingredients.name: Aged kimchi
ingredients.explanation: Fermented napa cabbage — tangy, funky, and spicy. The backbone of Korean cuisine, aged 6+ months for this stew.

ingredients.name: Gochugaru
ingredients.explanation: Korean red pepper flakes — smoky, slightly sweet heat. Less sharp than Indian red chili powder.

dishes.explanation: Korea's ultimate comfort food and the most commonly cooked dish in Korean homes. The longer the kimchi has fermented, the deeper and more complex the stew becomes.

culturalTerms.explanation: A thick Korean stew — heartier than guk (soup), eaten as a main dish with rice
Extra-aged kimchi (6+ months) — preferred for this stew for its deep, complex sourness

dishes.description: Paper-thin slices of beef marinated in a sweet-savory blend of soy sauce, Asian pear, garlic, and sesame oil, then grilled or pan-fried until caramelized. Wrapped in crisp lettuce leaves with rice and ssamjang paste. If you love the sweet-smoky char of tandoori seekh kebabs, bulgogi hits similar notes — but sweeter, more delicate, and without the heavy spice.

ingredients.name: Asian pear
ingredients.explanation: Used as a natural meat tenderizer — adds subtle sweetness. Korean secret to melt-in-your-mouth beef.

dishes.explanation: Literally 'fire meat' — one of Korea's most internationally famous dishes. The sweet soy marinade caramelizes beautifully over heat. Wrap in lettuce with rice for the full experience.

culturalTerms.explanation: Fire — refers to the grilling method
Wrapping meat and rice in lettuce leaves — the traditional way to eat Korean BBQ

dishes.description: Chewy, dense rice cake cylinders simmered in a glossy, sweet-and-fiery gochujang sauce with fish cakes and boiled eggs. Korea's most iconic street food — the texture is unlike anything in Indian cuisine, imagine a chewier, denser version of idli pieces swimming in a sweet-spicy gravy. Addictively spicy with a satisfying bounce in every bite.

ingredients.name: Rice cakes
ingredients.explanation: Tteok — chewy cylinders made from pounded rice flour. Dense and satisfyingly bouncy, nothing like fluffy rice.

ingredients.name: Gochujang
ingredients.explanation: Fermented red chili paste — sweet, spicy, and umami-rich. The soul of this dish's glossy red sauce.

ingredients.name: Fish cake
ingredients.explanation: Eomuk — pressed fish paste shaped into sheets. Mild, spongy, absorbs the spicy sauce.

dishes.explanation: The quintessential Korean street food — you'll see it at every street stall and convenience store. The sauce thickens as it cooks, coating each rice cake in glossy red heat. Spice level is real.

culturalTerms.explanation: Korean rice cake — chewy, dense, made from pounded rice flour
Fish cake — processed fish paste shaped into sheets, a tteokbokki staple

dishes.description: Thick slices of unseasoned pork belly grilled at your table on a charcoal grill, then wrapped in lettuce or perilla leaves with raw garlic, ssamjang dipping paste, and kimchi. A communal, interactive dining experience — everyone grills and wraps together. Similar vibe to a DIY tandoori platter, but the meat is unspiced and you build each bite yourself with condiments.

ingredients.name: Perilla leaves
ingredients.explanation: Kkaennip — aromatic, slightly minty leaf from the sesame family. Unique herbal flavor with no Indian equivalent.

ingredients.name: Ssamjang
ingredients.explanation: Thick dipping paste — soybean paste + chili paste blended together. Savory, sweet, spicy.

dishes.explanation: Korea's most popular social dining experience. The name means 'three-layer meat' for the visible layers of lean and fat. Price is typically per person and includes unlimited lettuce, garlic, and banchan.

culturalTerms.explanation: Three — the three visible layers of meat and fat in pork belly
The wrap — building a perfect lettuce parcel with meat, rice, garlic, and paste

dishes.description: A bubbling stew of silky, uncurdled soft tofu in a spicy seafood broth with clams, shrimp, and a raw egg cracked in at the table. Served sizzling in a stone pot. The soft tofu melts on your tongue like a spicy, Korean version of paneer in a light gravy — but much silkier and more delicate. The egg cooks in the residual heat as you stir.

ingredients.name: Gochugaru
ingredients.explanation: Korean red pepper flakes — fruity, smoky heat that colours the broth a deep red.

dishes.explanation: Lighter than kimchi jjigae but equally warming. The raw egg cooks in the bubbling pot at your table — stir it in for a silky, protein-rich broth. Available in seafood, pork, or vegetable versions.

culturalTerms.explanation: Extra-soft, uncurdled tofu — silkier and more delicate than firm tofu or paneer
The stone/clay pot it's served in — keeps the stew bubbling at the table

dishes.description: A large, crispy savory pancake packed with whole green onions, squid, shrimp, and clams in an egg-flour batter. Served with tangy soy-vinegar dipping sauce. Think of it as a Korean version of a besan chilla or rava uttapam — but loaded with seafood, crispier on the outside, and served with a vinegary dip instead of chutney. Traditionally eaten on rainy days with rice wine.
dishes.explanation: A rainy-day tradition — Koreans say the sizzle of the pancake sounds like rain. Best shared as an appetizer. Pairs perfectly with makgeolli (milky rice wine).

culturalTerms.explanation: Seafood — the mix of squid, shrimp, and shellfish
'Pa' means green onion, 'jeon' means pan-fried — a green onion pancake

dishes.description: Chunky chicken pieces stir-fried on a large flat pan at your table with sweet potato, cabbage, rice cakes, and a spicy gochujang-based sauce. At the end, fried rice is made on the same pan with the leftover sauce. Imagine a cross between a spicy chicken kadhai and a tawa preparation — the chicken is saucy and bold, the vegetables soak up the marinade, and the closing fried rice act is unforgettable.

ingredients.name: Gochujang
ingredients.explanation: Fermented red chili paste — provides the sweet, spicy base sauce.

ingredients.name: Rice cakes
ingredients.explanation: Tteok — chewy rice cylinders that absorb the spicy sauce.

ingredients.name: Perilla leaves
ingredients.explanation: Aromatic herb leaf from the sesame family — adds a fresh, minty note.

dishes.explanation: A Chuncheon specialty that's become wildly popular nationwide. Cooked at the table on a large flat pan — the interactive cooking is part of the fun. Always order the bokkeumbap (fried rice) finish.

culturalTerms.explanation: Chicken — the star protein
Fried rice — made at the end with leftover sauce on the same pan. Don't skip this.

dishes.description: Thick, hand-cut wheat noodles in a milky anchovy or clam broth, topped with zucchini and green onions. The noodles are fresh, not dried — flat, chewy, and slightly rough-textured so they grip the broth. Similar comfort to a bowl of dal chawal meets chicken soup — simple, nourishing, and warming. A go-to meal when you want something gentle on the stomach.

ingredients.name: Anchovy broth
ingredients.explanation: Light broth made from dried anchovies and kelp — umami-rich but clean-tasting.

dishes.explanation: Literally 'knife noodles' — the dough is rolled flat and cut by hand, giving each noodle a rustic, uneven shape. A humble but deeply satisfying meal, especially in winter.

culturalTerms.explanation: Knife — the noodles are hand-cut, not extruded through a machine
Noodle soup — a broad term for any noodle-in-broth dish

dishes.description: Thick wheat noodles drenched in a glossy, jet-black sauce made from fermented black bean paste (chunjang), diced pork, and onions. Korea's most popular delivery food and a comfort classic. The rich, savory-sweet black bean sauce is unlike anything in Indian cuisine — imagine a deeply umami, slightly sweet gravy coating chewy noodles. Koreans eat this on moving day and Valentine's Day alike.

ingredients.name: Chunjang
ingredients.explanation: Korean black bean paste — fermented from soybeans, deeply savory and slightly sweet. The source of the jet-black color.

dishes.explanation: Originally a Korean-Chinese dish, now fully adopted as comfort food. The black color can be surprising but the taste is mild and savory, not spicy at all. Comes with yellow pickled radish (danmuji) on the side.

culturalTerms.explanation: Korean fermented black bean paste — the base of the jet-black sauce
Yellow pickled radish — the crunchy, sweet-tangy side dish always served with jajangmyeon

dishes.description: A clear, deeply flavored soup with whole beef short ribs slow-simmered for hours until the meat falls off the bone. Served with glass noodles, radish, and egg garnish. The rich, clean bone broth is reminiscent of a well-made mutton yakhni or paya shorba — light in color but intensely meaty in flavor. A restorative, elegant soup often served at special occasions.

ingredients.name: Korean radish
ingredients.explanation: Mu — larger and denser than Indian mooli, with a slightly sweeter flavor when cooked.

dishes.explanation: Hours of slow simmering produce a clear, deeply flavorful bone broth. The short ribs are so tender the meat slides off. A premium dish — you'll often see it at celebrations and family gatherings.

culturalTerms.explanation: Ribs — specifically beef short ribs, one of Korea's prized cuts
Soup — a clear, broth-based soup, different from jjigae (thick stew)

dishes.description: A crispy-on-the-outside, gooey-on-the-inside street pancake filled with a molten mixture of brown sugar, cinnamon, and crushed peanuts. Pressed flat on a griddle until golden and caramelized. Korea's answer to a malpua or a stuffed paratha gone sweet — the dough is yeasted so it's pillowy, and the filling turns into hot liquid caramel. Careful, the filling is volcanic when fresh off the pan.
dishes.explanation: Korea's favourite winter street food. Lines form at hotteok stands when the temperature drops. The contrast between the crispy shell and molten sugar filling is irresistible. Vegetarian-friendly.

culturalTerms.explanation: From the Chinese character for 'barbarian' — the dish has Chinese origins
Cake/pancake — here refers to the filled, griddled dough

dishes.description: Korean blood sausage — pig intestine stuffed with sweet potato glass noodles, barley, pork blood, and vegetables, then steamed. Served sliced with salt-and-pepper dip or in a spicy stew. Not ice cream! This is an adventurous choice — the closest Indian parallel might be the concept of organ-meat dishes like boti or kaleji. The glass noodle filling gives it a unique chewy texture inside a tender casing.

ingredients.name: Pig intestine casing
ingredients.explanation: Natural casing — cleaned and filled with the noodle-blood mixture. Traditional sausage-making technique.

ingredients.name: Pork blood
ingredients.explanation: Coagulated blood mixed into the filling — adds iron-rich, earthy depth.

dishes.explanation: A beloved street food that often surprises foreigners who expect ice cream from the name. Locals eat it dipped in salt mixed with pepper. Also commonly served in sundae-gukbap (blood sausage rice soup).

culturalTerms.explanation: Pronounced 'soon-deh' — Korean blood sausage, NOT the ice cream dessert
A hearty rice soup with sliced sundae — popular hangover cure

dishes.description: Tender, thinly sliced boiled pork belly served with napa cabbage wraps, raw garlic, salted shrimp paste (saeujeot), and fermented radish kimchi. A large-format sharing dish — you wrap the pork in cabbage with condiments to build each bite. Think of it as a Korean version of a DIY kebab roll — soft meat wrapped in a leaf with pungent condiments. The salted shrimp paste adds an umami kick unlike anything in Indian cuisine.

ingredients.name: Saeujeot
ingredients.explanation: Salted fermented shrimp — tiny pink shrimp in brine, intensely salty and funky. A tiny bit goes a long way.

ingredients.name: Radish kimchi
ingredients.explanation: Kkakdugi — cubed radish kimchi, crunchy and tangy. Adds texture contrast to the soft pork.

dishes.explanation: A premium sharing dish meant for groups (serves 2-3). The pork is boiled with ginger and doenjang to remove gaminess, resulting in clean, tender slices. The price is for a large platter — good value when shared.

culturalTerms.explanation: Means 'wrapped' — the dish is all about building wraps at the table
Fermented salted shrimp — a key Korean condiment, adds explosive umami to each bite
